Alipurduar.title: Alipurduar, West Bengal
info: Formed on 25th June 2014, it is the 20th district of West Bengal.
Located in the Dooars region, known for its immense natural beauty, forests, wildlife, and tea gardens.
Home to two major protected areas: Buxa Tiger Reserve and Jaldapara National Park.
Serves as the gateway to Bhutan and the northeastern states of India.
The economy is heavily dependent on the tea industry, timber, and tourism.

Bankura.title: Bankura, West Bengal
info: Located in the western part of the state, it is a part of the historic Rarh region.
Famous for its terracotta temples, particularly in the town of Bishnupur.
The Bankura Horse, a terracotta craft, is a globally recognized symbol of Indian folk art.
Mukutmanipur Dam, on the Kangsabati River, is a major tourist attraction.
The economy is based on agriculture, traditional crafts like pottery and weaving, and mining.

Birbhum.title: Birbhum, West Bengal
info: Known as the 'land of red soil', its landscape is characterized by undulating laterite soil.
Famous for Visva-Bharati University in Santiniketan, founded by Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore.
A major religious hub, home to the Tarapith Temple, a revered Shakti Peeth.
Hosts the famous Poush Mela, an annual fair and festival that draws artists and tourists.
Bolinathpur is renowned for its traditional Bengali Kantha stitch work.

Cooch Behar.title: Cooch Behar, West Bengal
info: A former princely state located in the northeastern part of West Bengal.
Renowned for the magnificent Cooch Behar Palace, designed in the Italian Renaissance style.
The district has numerous large water bodies (dighis), with Sagardighi being the most famous.
The Madan Mohan Temple is a significant center of pilgrimage for Vaishnavites.
Agriculture is the mainstay of the economy, with jute, tobacco, and rice being the main crops.

Dakshin Dinajpur.title: Dakshin Dinajpur, West Bengal
info: Carved out of the erstwhile West Dinajpur district in 1992.
An agriculture-based district with rice, jute, and wheat as the primary produce.
Home to the ancient ruins of Bangarh, the historical capital of the Koti Varsha region.
The district has a rich folk culture, including the traditional 'Khan' theatre form.
The Bairhatta region contains ruins associated with the epic Mahabharata.

Darjeeling.title: Darjeeling, West Bengal
info: A world-famous hill station located in the Lesser Himalayas.
Globally acclaimed for its unique 'Darjeeling Tea' and sprawling tea estates.
Home to the Darjeeling Himalayan Railway, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, popularly known as the 'Toy Train'.
Offers breathtaking views of Kanchenjunga, the world's third-highest mountain peak.
Padmaja Naidu Himalayan Zoological Park is renowned for its conservation programs for the Red Panda and Snow Leopard.

Hooghly.title: Hooghly, West Bengal
info: A historically rich district on the west bank of the Hooghly River.
Has a strong colonial legacy with former settlements of the Portuguese (Bandel), Dutch (Chinsurah), and French (Chandannagar).
The Bandel Church is one of the oldest Christian churches in Bengal.
The Hooghly Imambara is a famous Shia pilgrimage center known for its large clock tower.
An industrially advanced district, known for jute mills and the Hindustan Motors factory.

Howrah.title: Howrah, West Bengal
info: Located on the western bank of the Hooghly River, it is the twin city of Kolkata.
Dominated by the iconic Howrah Bridge (Rabindra Setu), a symbol of Bengal.
Howrah Station is one of the oldest and busiest railway complexes in India.
Home to Belur Math, the headquarters of the Ramakrishna Math and Mission.
The Acharya Jagadish Chandra Bose Indian Botanic Garden houses the Great Banyan Tree, with the largest canopy in the world.

Jalpaiguri.title: Jalpaiguri, West Bengal
info: Located in the Dooars region in the foothills of the Himalayas.
Known for its extensive tea gardens, dense forests, and rich biodiversity.
Home to Gorumara National Park and Chapramari Wildlife Sanctuary, famous for rhinoceros and elephants.
The Teesta River flows through the district, offering opportunities for river rafting.
Its economy is driven by tea, timber, and tourism.

Jhargram.title: Jhargram, West Bengal
info: Carved out of Paschim Medinipur in 2017, it is known for its wooded beauty and tribal culture.
The landscape is a part of the Chota Nagpur Plateau, characterized by red laterite soil.
A popular eco-tourism destination with attractions like the Jhargram Raj Palace and Kendua bird sanctuary.
It is a significant center for the Santhal tribe and their vibrant culture.
The district is rich in forests of Sal, Mahua, and Piyal.

Kalimpong.title: Kalimpong, West Bengal
info: A serene hill station that became a district in 2017, separated from Darjeeling.
Known for its panoramic views of the Kanchenjunga range, Buddhist monasteries, and colonial architecture.
A major center for horticulture, particularly for exotic orchids and gladioli.
Deolo Hill is the highest point in Kalimpong, offering stunning 360-degree views.
Zang Dhok Palri Phodang (Durpin Monastery) holds rare Tibetan Buddhist scriptures.

Kolkata.title: Kolkata, West Bengal
info: The capital of West Bengal and the former capital of British India.
Widely regarded as the 'Cultural Capital of India'.
Famous for its grand colonial architecture, including the Victoria Memorial and St. Paul's Cathedral.
Durga Puja in Kolkata is a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.
Home to the Indian Museum, the oldest and largest museum in India.

Malda.title: Malda, West Bengal
info: Historically significant as the seat of power for Bengal during the Sultanate period.
Home to the ancient ruined cities of Gour and Pandua, which served as the capitals of Bengal.
World-famous for its distinct varieties of mangoes like Fazli, Himsagar, and Laxmanbhog.
The Adina Mosque in Pandua was one of the largest mosques in the Indian subcontinent.
The economy is primarily based on agriculture, with mango cultivation, jute, and sericulture being vital.

Murshidabad.title: Murshidabad, West Bengal
info: The last capital city of independent Bengal before British rule.
Rich in Nawabi-era history, with numerous palaces, mosques, and tombs.
The Hazarduari Palace, or the palace with a thousand doors, is the most famous landmark.
Famous for its silk industry, producing the renowned Murshidabad silk.
The Katra Mosque contains the tomb of Nawab Murshid Quli Khan.

Nadia.title: Nadia, West Bengal
info: A district with immense religious and cultural significance.
Nabadwip is revered as the birthplace of the 15th-century saint Chaitanya Mahaprabhu.
Mayapur is the world headquarters of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (ISKCON).
Krishnanagar, the district headquarters, is famous for its exquisite clay dolls ('Matir Putul').
The historic town of Plassey (Palashi), the site of the pivotal Battle of 1757, is located here.

North 24 Parganas.title: North 24 Parganas, West Bengal
info: The most populous district in West Bengal and the second most populous in India.
Stretches from the northern suburbs of Kolkata to the border with Bangladesh.
Barrackpore, a major town, played a key role in the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
A major industrial and agricultural district.
Taki, a town on the banks of the Ichamati River, is a popular weekend destination on the Indo-Bangladesh border.

Paschim Medinipur.title: Paschim Medinipur, West Bengal
info: A large district in the south-western part of the state with diverse geography.
Midnapore town has a rich history related to the Indian independence movement.
Gopegarh Heritage Park is a popular eco-tourism spot.
The ancient Kurumbera Fort is a protected monument with a unique blend of Odia and Mughal architecture.
The district is known for its Patachitra art, a form of traditional scroll painting.

Paschim Bardhaman.title: Paschim Bardhaman, West Bengal
info: Formed in 2017, it is the primary industrial zone of West Bengal.
Known as the 'Ruhr of India' due to its vast coalfields (Raniganj) and steel plants (Durgapur, Asansol).
Asansol is the district headquarters and the second-largest city in the state.
The Maithon and Panchet dams on the Damodar river are popular picnic and tourist spots.
The Kalyaneswari Temple near Maithon is a revered pilgrimage site.

tourist_places.name: Maithon Dam
tourist_places.location: Near Asansol, Paschim Bardhaman, West Bengal

tourist_places.name: Kalyaneswari Temple
tourist_places.location: Near Maithon, Paschim Bardhaman, West Bengal

Purba Bardhaman.title: Purba Bardhaman, West Bengal
info: Formed in 2017 after the bifurcation of Bardhaman district.
Known as the 'Rice Bowl of Bengal' for its extensive and fertile paddy fields.
Bardhaman city is famous for its sweets like Mihidana and Sitabhog.
The town of Kalna is famous for the 108 Shiva Temples (Naba Kailash), built in two concentric circles.
The Curzon Gate (Vijay Toran) is a prominent landmark in Bardhaman town.

Purba Medinipur.title: Purba Medinipur, West Bengal
info: A coastal district known for its popular sea beaches.
Digha, Mandarmani, and Shankarpur are major seaside resorts attracting tourists.
Haldia is a major river port and a significant industrial hub in West Bengal.
The district is a major producer of cashews, betel leaves, and fish.
Tamluk, the district headquarters, is a historic port town identified with the ancient Tamralipta Kingdom.

Purulia.title: Purulia, West Bengal
info: The westernmost district of West Bengal, characterized by the rugged beauty of the Chota Nagpur Plateau.
Famous for the Chhau dance, a vibrant and energetic martial folk dance, recognized by UNESCO.
The Ayodhya Hills are a major tourist attraction, offering scenic landscapes, waterfalls, and trekking routes.
The district has a significant tribal population, contributing to its rich folk heritage.
Garpanchkot, at the foothills of Panchet Hill, offers a blend of natural beauty and historical ruins.

tourist_places.name: Garpanchkot
tourist_places.location: Near Panchet Dam, Purulia, West Bengal

South 24 Parganas.title: South 24 Parganas, West Bengal
info: Extends from the southern suburbs of Kolkata to the Bay of Bengal.
Home to the Indian portion of the Sundarbans, the world's largest mangrove forest.
The Sundarbans National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a critical habitat for the Royal Bengal Tiger.
Gangasagar (Sagar Island) is a major Hindu pilgrimage site where the Ganges meets the sea.
The economy is based on agriculture, aquaculture, and tourism related to the Sundarbans.

tourist_places.name: Gangasagar (Kapil Muni Temple)
tourist_places.location: Sagar Island, South 24 Parganas, West Bengal

Uttar Dinajpur.title: Uttar Dinajpur, West Bengal
info: Formed in 1992 by the division of the West Dinajpur district.
Raiganj Wildlife Sanctuary, popularly known as Kulik Bird Sanctuary, is a major attraction.
Kulik is one of the largest bird sanctuaries in Asia, hosting a vast population of migratory birds.
The economy is primarily driven by agriculture, with a focus on rice and jute.
The district serves as a vital corridor connecting North Bengal with the rest of the state.
